questions.prompt: A child’s weight is plotted at the 85th percentile on a growth chart. What does this percentile indicate?

options.A: About 85% of children of similar age and sex weigh less, and about 15% weigh more
options.B: The child weighs about 85% of the ideal weight for their age
options.C: About 85% of the child’s expected growth has already occurred
options.D: The child has an 85% likelihood of having normal growth

questions.rationale: The percentile indicates a child’s rank relative to peers of the same age and sex, meaning most children weigh less and a smaller proportion weigh more.

questions.prompt: A community health worker records a child’s weight once and wants to assess the child’s growth. Which approach is most appropriate?

options.A: Plot measurements accurately on the growth chart and use serial measurements over time to assess growth patterns
options.B: Use the single measurement alone because plotting is not needed for interpretation
options.C: Average three weights taken on consecutive days to determine the child’s growth pattern
options.D: Rely on a single measurement because it provides adequate information to assess growth

questions.rationale: Growth assessment requires accurately plotted measurements over time, as a single measurement does not adequately reflect growth patterns.

questions.prompt: Which growth pattern should prompt further investigation?

options.A: Unexpected downward movement on the growth curves, especially before crossing two percentile lines
options.B: Any single measurement below the 50th percentile
options.C: Investigation only after a child has crossed two percentile lines
options.D: Any upward movement on the growth curves from a prior measurement

questions.rationale: Unexpected downward movement on growth curves may indicate growth faltering and should be investigated before a child crosses two percentile lines.
